Required.name: Foundations of Computer Science I
Required.description: Introduction to the mathematical foundations of computer science. Topics include logic, proof techniques, and key concepts of mathematical structures such as sequences, sets, functions, relations, and graphs. Not for credit in addition to CSE 215.
Required.requirements: Prerequisite(s): AMS 151 or MAT 125 or MAT 131 or level 6 on the mathematics placement examination

Required.name: Introduction to Object-Oriented Programming
Required.description: An introduction to procedural and object-oriented programming methodology. Covers program structure, conditional and iterative programming, procedures, arrays, object classes, encapsulation, inheritance, polymorphism, file I/O, and exceptions. Includes a required lab. This course has been designated as a High Demand/Controlled Access course.
Required.requirements: Prerequisite(s): Level 5 or higher on the math placement exam. Advisory prerequisite: CSE 101, CSE 103, or ISE 108.

Required.name: Foundations of Computer Science II
Required.description: A continuation of CSE 113 covering mathematical foundations, counting techniques, graph theory, and finite automata.
Required.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 113 or CSE 215 or CSE 150; CSE major

Required.name: Data Structures
Required.description: Extension of programming methodology to data storage and manipulation on complex datasets. Covers stacks, queues, lists, binary trees, heaps, priority queues, balanced trees, graphs, recursion, and sorting/searching algorithms.
Required.requirements: Prerequisite(s): C or higher in CSE 114

Required.name: Systems Fundamentals I
Required.description: Introduces systems-level programming using C and assembly language. Covers data representation, instructions, control structures, memory management, pointers, function calls, linking/loading, and foundational computer architecture and networks.
Required.requirements: Prerequisite(s): C or higher in CSE 214 or co-requisite CSE 260 and CSE major

Required.name: Principles of Programming Languages
Required.description: Introduction to programming language paradigms including functional and logic programming. Covers scoping, binding, type systems, memory, and language implementation concepts such as parsing, semantic analysis, and code generation.
Required.requirements: Prerequisite(s): C or higher in CSE 214, CSE 216, or CSE 260; CSE or DAS major

Required.name: Fundamentals of Software Development
Required.description: Introduction to systematic design, development, and testing of software systems, including event-driven programming, databases, secure computing principles, and version control. Students construct large, robust programs.
Required.requirements: Prerequisite(s): C or higher in CSE 216, CSE 260, or CSE 307; CSE major

Required.name: Systems Fundamentals II
Required.description: Introduces operating systems, compilers, concurrency, and performance analysis. Focuses on APIs for interacting with an OS and memory management, error handling, and threaded programming.
Required.requirements: Prerequisite(s): C or higher in CSE 220 and CSE major

Required.name: Analysis of Algorithms
Required.description: Mathematical analysis of computer algorithms including searching, sorting, matrix multiplication, FFT, and graph algorithms. Covers time and space complexity, upper/lower/average-case analysis, and introduction to NP-completeness.
Required.requirements: Prerequisite(s): C or higher in CSE 113 or CSE 150 or CSE 215 or MAT 200 or MAT 250; MAT 211 or AMS 210; CSE 214 or CSE 260; CSE or MAT or DAS major
Required.restrictions: CSE, MAT, or DAS majors only

Required.name: Cloud Computing
Required.description: Focus on deploying and scaling modern online services, using mature technologies across distributed servers for high-availability systems.
Required.requirements: Prerequisite(s): C or higher in CSE 316 and CSE 320; CSE major

Required.name: Software Engineering
Required.description: Introduction to software engineering concepts and tools. Covers requirements/specifications, design methodologies, implementation, integration, testing, project management, maintenance, and human factors.
Required.requirements: Prerequisite(s): C or higher in CSE 316; U4 standing; CSE major

Specializations.description: The specialization in artificial intelligence and data science emphasizes modern approaches for building intelligent systems using machine learning. It requires four courses selected from the list below, including at least two core courses.
Specializations.requirements: Students may declare their participation in the specialization after completing two core courses. Courses used to satisfy required advanced courses may not be used to satisfy specialization requirements.

core_courses.name: Introduction to Data Science
core_courses.description: Introduces theoretical concepts and practical methods for extracting knowledge from data using machine learning and statistics. Covers preprocessing, modeling, prediction, evaluation, and visualization with Python.
core_courses.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 214 or CSE 260; AMS 310; CSE or DAS major.

core_courses.name: Artificial Intelligence
core_courses.description: Covers problem representations, search algorithms, game-playing, theorem proving, and cognitive simulation. Includes topics in current AI research.
core_courses.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 316 or CSE 351; CSE or DAS major.

core_courses.name: Machine Learning
core_courses.description: Covers fundamental concepts, models, and algorithms for systems that learn from data. Applications include vision, NLP, and robotics.
core_courses.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 316 or CSE 351; CSE or DAS major. Pre- or corequisite: AMS 310 or AMS 311 or AMS 412.

core_courses.name: Statistical Methods for Data Science
core_courses.description: Introduces applied statistical inference and data analysis techniques, including estimation, hypothesis testing, Bayesian inference, and likelihood methods, with Python implementation.
core_courses.requirements: Prerequisite(s): C or higher in CSE 214 or CSE 260; AMS 310; CSE or DAS major.

electives.name: Human-Computer Interaction
electives.description: Survey of Human-Computer Interaction concepts, principles, and design techniques, with a focus on user experience and interface design.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 214 or CSE 230 or CSE 260 or ISE 208.

electives.name: Fundamentals of Computer Vision
electives.description: Introduces core techniques in visual information processing, including image formation, segmentation, and object recognition.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 214 or CSE 230 or CSE 260; AMS 210 or MAT 211; CSE or ISE or DAS major.

electives.name: Introduction to Visualization
electives.description: Covers visualization and visual analytics for understanding complex data in science, business, and medicine. Includes hands-on projects using visualization libraries.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 214 or CSE 260; MAT 211 or AMS 210; AMS 110 or AMS 310; CSE or ISE or DAS major.

electives.name: Scripting Languages
electives.description: Covers principles and practical applications of scripting languages for rapid development, automation, and software composition.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 214 or CSE 260; CSE or ISE or DAS major; U3 or U4 standing.

electives.name: Natural Language Processing
electives.description: Introduces core NLP techniques and applications such as text classification, information extraction, question answering, and translation.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 316 or CSE 351; CSE or DAS major.

electives.name: Logic
electives.description: Covers propositional calculus, quantification theory, proofs, models, completeness, and Goedel’s incompleteness theorem.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 113 or CSE 150 or CSE 215 or MAT 200 or MAT 250.

electives.name: Introduction to Robotics
electives.description: Covers coordinate transformation, kinematics, dynamics, control systems, sensors, and path planning. Includes lab work using LEGO Robot Kit.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): AMS 161 or MAT 127 or MAT 132; AMS 210 or MAT 211 or MEC 262.

electives.name: Special Topics in Computer Science
electives.description: A lecture or seminar course on a current topic in computer science. May be repeated as the topic changes.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 214 or CSE 260; CSE or ISE major.

electives.name: Research in Computer Science
electives.description: Independent research under faculty supervision. May not be taken for more than six credits. Only three credits may count toward technical electives.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): Permission of instructor and department.

Specializations.notes: *Special topic or research project must be in artificial intelligence or data science.

Specializations.description: The specialization in human-computer interaction emphasizes both the psychology aspects of effective human-computer interactions and the technical design and implementation of systems for those interactions. It requires four core courses, two electives, and a project. Students may declare their participation in the specialization after completing two core courses.

core_courses.name: Human-Computer Interaction
core_courses.prerequisites: CSE 214 or CSE 230 or CSE 260 or ISE 208

core_courses.name: Fundamentals of Computer Graphics
core_courses.prerequisites: C or higher in CSE 220; CSE major

core_courses.name: User Interface Development
core_courses.prerequisites: CSE 214 or CSE 260; CSE or ISE major
core_courses.notes: Offered as both CSE 333 and ISE 333.

electives: CSE 390 - Special Topics in Computer Science *
PSY 369 - Special Topics in Cognition and Perception
notes: *Special topic must be in human-computer interaction.
Two electives are required, including at least one CSE course.
The project may not be applied toward the requirements of another specialization.
project_options: CSE 495 - Senior Honors Research Project I
CSE 496 - Senior Honors Research Project II

Specializations.description: The specialization in Security and Privacy prepares students for a career as a security engineer, threat analyst, or security and privacy researcher. The courses are taught by computer science faculty affiliated with the National Security Institute and cover both fundamental and advanced topics. Students may declare their participation in the specialization after completing one core course and at least two additional courses listed below.

notes: Students must take CSE 331 and one course from CSE 360, CSE 361, CSE 362, or CSE 363 as core courses.
Three electives are required, not including any course taken as a core course.
At most one course from each elective item group may be used to satisfy the specialization requirements.

core_courses.name: Computer Security Fundamentals
core_courses.description: Introduces the basic concepts and terminology of computer security. Covers topics such as cryptography, operating systems security, network security, and language-based security.

options.name: Software Security
options.description: Covers principles and practices of securing software systems, including software vulnerabilities, analysis techniques, malware detection, secure development, and sandboxing.

options.name: Web Security
options.description: Covers all aspects of web security, including browser, web server, and web application security. Topics include SOP, vulnerabilities, penetration testing, and monetization.

options.name: Mobile Security
options.description: Examines security technologies for mobile platforms such as Android and iOS, covering app security, sandboxing, hardware-level features, and OS internals.

options.name: Offensive Security
options.description: Hands-on course in understanding security problems through an adversarial mindset. Covers vulnerability discovery, exploitation, and ethical hacking techniques.

courses.name: Computer Networks
courses.prerequisites: C or higher in CSE 214 or CSE 260; CSE 220 or ISE 218; CSE or ISE major
courses.description: Overview of computer networks and Internet architecture including layers, protocols, routing, addressing, LANs, and wireless networking.

courses.name: Software Security
courses.prerequisites: CSE 220; CSE major

courses.name: Web Security
courses.prerequisites: CSE 220; CSE major

courses.name: Mobile Security
courses.prerequisites: CSE 220; CSE major

courses.name: Offensive Security
courses.prerequisites: CSE 220; CSE major

courses.name: Compiler Design
courses.prerequisites: C or higher in CSE 213 or CSE 350; CSE 220; CSE major

courses.name: Operating Systems
courses.prerequisites: C or higher in CSE 320 or ESE 280; CSE or ECE major
courses.description: Covers modern operating systems including memory management, concurrency, and protection.

alternative.name: Cloud Computing
alternative.prerequisites: C or higher in CSE 316 and CSE 320; CSE major

alternative.name: Advanced Systems Programming in UNIX/C
alternative.prerequisites: C or higher in CSE 320; CSE major

courses.name: Special Topics in Computer Science *
courses.prerequisites: CSE 214 or CSE 260; CSE or ISE major
courses.notes: *The special topic must be in computer security.

courses.name: Senior Honors Research Project II
courses.notes: CSE 495 and CSE 496 are alternatives and may be taken as part of the specialization if the project topic is in computer security.

Specializations.description: The specialization in Systems Software Development prepares students for a career in software applications development or systems software development. Students may declare their participation in this specialization after completing two of the listed courses.
Specializations.requirements: Five of the following courses are required, at most two of which may be drawn from CSE 331, CSE 360–CSE 363.

courses.title: Compiler Design
courses.description: Topics include formal description of programming languages, lexical and syntax analysis, symbol tables, code generation, and interpreters. Includes a semester-long compiler implementation project.
courses.prerequisites: C or higher in CSE 213 or CSE 350; CSE 220; CSE major

courses.title: Operating Systems
courses.description: Introduces modern operating system structures. Topics include virtual memory, concurrency, protection, and resource allocation. Students design and build OS kernel modules.
courses.prerequisites: C or higher in CSE 320 or ESE 280; CSE major or ECE major

courses.title: Computer Networks
courses.description: Overview of computer networks and the Internet. Covers Internet architecture, TCP/IP, routing, Ethernet, and wireless LANs.
courses.prerequisites: C or higher in CSE 214 or CSE 260; CSE 220 or ISE 218; CSE major or ISE major

courses.title: Systems Administration
courses.description: Covers installation, configuration, and management of computer systems and networks. Emphasizes scripting, automation, and server administration.
courses.prerequisites: CSE 306 or permission of instructor

courses.title: Computer Security Fundamentals
courses.description: Introduces core security concepts such as cryptography, operating system security, and network defense.
courses.prerequisites: CSE 220; CSE major

courses.title: Cloud Computing
courses.description: Focuses on deploying and scaling distributed online services. Topics include datacenter architecture, scalability, fault tolerance, and cloud APIs.
courses.prerequisites: C or higher in CSE 316 and CSE 320; CSE major

courses.title: Software Security
courses.description: Covers techniques for building secure software. Topics include vulnerability detection, exploit prevention, malware analysis, and secure programming.
courses.prerequisites: CSE 220; CSE major

courses.title: Web Security
courses.description: Focuses on browser, web server, and web application security. Topics include JavaScript security, protocol vulnerabilities, penetration testing, and social engineering.
courses.prerequisites: CSE 220; CSE major

courses.title: Mobile Security
courses.description: Explores security in mobile platforms such as Android and iOS. Topics include app sandboxing, permissions, and hardware-level security features.
courses.prerequisites: CSE 220; CSE major

courses.title: Offensive Security
courses.description: Hands-on exploration of security vulnerabilities and exploits. Covers reverse engineering, malware analysis, social engineering, and ethical hacking.
courses.prerequisites: CSE 220; CSE major

courses.title: Advanced Systems Programming in UNIX/C
courses.description: Teaches secure, reliable, and portable systems programming in C and Unix. Includes substantial programming and a course project.
courses.prerequisites: C or higher in CSE 320; CSE major

courses.title: Special Topics in Computer Science
courses.description: A lecture or seminar course on a current topic in computer science. Must focus on systems software development to count toward this specialization.
courses.prerequisites: CSE 214 or CSE 260; CSE or ISE major

Specializations.notes: Special topics (CSE 390) must specifically be in systems software development.

Specializations.description: The specialization in game programming prepares students for a career as either a professional game developer or researcher. Game graphics and multiplayer network programming techniques are stressed. The specialization also emphasizes original game development, game design methodology, and team projects and presentations.
Specializations.requirements: Students may declare their participation in the specialization after completing two core courses. It requires four core courses, two electives, and a project.

core_courses.name: Operating Systems
core_courses.description: Covers fundamental concepts of operating systems including process management, memory management, file systems, and system calls. Essential for understanding game engine architecture and performance optimization.

core_courses.name: Fundamentals of Computer Graphics
core_courses.description: Introduces core graphics concepts including rendering pipelines, 3D transformations, lighting models, texture mapping, and shader programming. Foundation for game graphics development.
core_courses.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 214 or CSE 260; AMS 210 or MAT 211; CSE or ISE major.

core_courses.name: 2D Game Programming
core_courses.description: Covers 2D game development including sprite rendering, collision detection, game physics, animation systems, and game design principles. Students develop complete 2D games.
core_courses.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 214 or CSE 260; CSE or ISE major.

core_courses.name: 3D Game Programming
core_courses.description: Advanced game development covering 3D rendering techniques, real-time graphics, game engine architecture, optimization, and multiplayer networking. Emphasizes team-based game projects.

electives.name: Computer Networks
electives.description: Covers network protocols, client-server architecture, socket programming, and multiplayer game networking. Essential for online multiplayer game development.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 214 or CSE 260; CSE 220.

electives.name: Fundamentals of Computer Vision
electives.description: Introduces core techniques in visual information processing, including image formation, segmentation, and object recognition. Applicable to AR/VR games and computer vision-based gameplay.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 214 or CSE 230 or CSE 260; AMS 210 or MAT 211; CSE or ISE or DAS major.

electives.name: Computer Security Fundamentals
electives.description: Introduces security principles including encryption, authentication, and secure system design. Important for preventing cheating and securing multiplayer games.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 220; CSE 303 or CSE 305.

electives.name: Introduction to Visualization
electives.description: Covers visualization and visual analytics for understanding complex data in science, business, and medicine. Includes techniques applicable to game analytics and debugging tools.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 214 or CSE 260; MAT 211 or AMS 210; AMS 110 or AMS 310; CSE or ISE or DAS major.

electives.name: Introduction to Multimedia Systems
electives.description: Covers multimedia data types, compression algorithms, streaming protocols, and multimedia application development. Relevant for game audio, video cutscenes, and streaming.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 214 or CSE 260; CSE or ISE major.

electives.name: Artificial Intelligence
electives.description: Covers problem representations, search algorithms, game-playing AI, theorem proving, and cognitive simulation. Essential for developing intelligent game NPCs and opponents.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 316 or CSE 351; CSE or DAS major.

electives.name: Machine Learning
electives.description: Covers fundamental concepts, models, and algorithms for systems that learn from data. Applications include adaptive game difficulty, procedural content generation, and player behavior prediction.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 316 or CSE 351; CSE or DAS major. Pre- or corequisite: AMS 310 or AMS 311 or AMS 412.

electives.name: Computational Geometry
electives.description: Covers geometric algorithms for collision detection, path planning, visibility determination, and spatial data structures. Critical for game physics and AI navigation.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): AMS 301 or CSE 373; CSE or ISE or DAS major.

electives.name: Advanced Multimedia Techniques
electives.description: Advanced topics in multimedia processing including real-time rendering, audio synthesis, and interactive media. Applicable to cutting-edge game audio and visual effects.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 334.

electives.name: Advanced Systems Programming in UNIX/C
electives.description: Advanced C programming and UNIX system programming including process control, interprocess communication, and system-level optimization. Relevant for game engine development.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): CSE 220; CSE 320 or CSE 306.

electives.name: Introduction to Robotics
electives.description: Covers coordinate transformation, kinematics, dynamics, control systems, sensors, and path planning. Applicable to physics simulation and robotic characters in games.
electives.requirements: Prerequisite(s): AMS 161 or MAT 127 or MAT 132; AMS 210 or MAT 211 or MEC 262.

Specializations.notes: Courses used to satisfy required advanced courses may not be used to satisfy specialization requirements. Students are encouraged to participate in game jams and develop portfolio projects.
